content: "Definitions." The Safe and Drug-Free Schools and Communities Act of 1994 defines abuse as the intentional inhalation of gas or vapors for altered consciousness, includes inhalants as drugs, and defines inhalants as legal products that can be abused. The Safe and Drug-Free Schools and Communities Act of 1994 defines abuse as intentional inhalation of gas or vapors for altered consciousness, including legal products that can be abused like whipped cream, air freshener, butane, or cooking spray. The term 'use' with respect to an inhalant means abuse of the inhalant. The findings are outlined in Section 2. Section 4002 of the Safe and Drug-Free Schools and Communities Act of 1994 is amended to include the abuse of inhalants in various paragraphs. It is noted that the number of children using inhalants doubled in the 10-year period preceding 1999, making inhalants the third most abused class of substances by children aged 12. Inhalants are the third most abused substances by children aged 12-14 in the US, after alcohol and tobacco. Inhalant vapors can cause instant and permanent damage to the brain, heart, and other organs, leading to Sudden Sniffing Death Syndrome. Education on the dangers of inhalant abuse is crucial in prevention. The Safe and Drug-Free Schools and Communities Act of 1994 is amended to include inhalant abuse prevention programs at the state level. This is crucial due to the harmful effects of inhalants on the brain, heart, and other organs, especially in children aged 12-14. Section 4116 of the Safe and Drug-Free Schools and Communities Act of 1994 is amended to include inhalant abuse prevention programs for all students from preschool through grade 12. In Section 4116 of the Safe and Drug-Free Schools and Communities Act of 1994, inhalant abuse prevention programs are added for all students from preschool through grade 12. Additionally, the amendment includes adding "and inhalant abuse" after "drug use" in subparagraph (C). SEC. 6. FEDERAL ACTIVITIES amends the Safe and Drug-Free Schools and Communities Act to include the abuse of inhalants. SEC. 7. MATERIALS also includes inhalant abuse in the Act. SEC. 8. QUALITY RATING adds inhalant abuse to the Act after tobacco.
